qas.question: When is it thought that early speakers of Sanskrit came to India?
What is the relationship between Indo-Iranian and Baltic languages?
From what direction did Sanskrit travel to come to India?
Sanskrit came from the north west and traveled to what present day countries?
What is the theory called dealing with the transfer of Sanskrit to India?

plausible_answers.text: the common features shared by Sanskrit and other Indo-European languages,

qas.question: What does the Ino-European migration theory explain?
When did the original speakers of Sanskrit migrate to the north-west?
What arrived in the Batic region during the second millenium BCE?

plausible_answers.text: that the original speakers of what became Sanskrit arrived in what is now India and Pakistan from the north-west

qas.question: What theory explains the different features of Sanskrit and other Indo-European languages?
To where did early speakers from the north-east bring Sanskrit?
Who arrived in India during the first millennium BCE?

plausible_answers.text: the Indo-Iranian tongues and the Baltic and Slavic languages

qas.question: Which languages share nothing in common with each other?
Little evidence exists to support which theory?

context: In order to explain <b5_0>the common features shared by <b7_0>Sanskrit<b7_0/> and other Indo-European languages,<b5_0/> many scholars have proposed the <a4_0><b9_0><b13_0>Indo-Aryan migration theory<b13_0/><b9_0/><a4_0/>, asserting <b8_0>that the <b11_0>original speakers<b11_0/> of what became Sanskrit arrived in what is now <a3_0><b10_0>India and Pakistan<b10_0/><a3_0/> from the <a2_0>north-west<b8_0/><a2_0/> some time during the <a0_0><b6_0>early second millennium BCE<b6_0/><a0_0/>. Evidence for such a theory includes the <a1_0>close<a1_0/> relationship between <b12_0>the Indo-Iranian tongues and the Baltic and Slavic languages<b12_0/>, vocabulary exchange with the non-Indo-European Uralic languages, and the nature of the attested Indo-European words for flora and fauna.
